title: Tina Nordlund
text:
Tina Cecilia Elisabeth Nordlund (born 19 March 1977) is a <a href="Swedes">Swedish</a> <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and former player, most recently an assistant coach at <a href="Ume%C3%A5%20IK">Umeå IK</a>. She is one of the most well known Swedish female footballers. In November 2000, she was awarded the <a href="Diamantbollen">Diamantbollen</a>, an annual award made to the best female player in Sweden, during the <a href="Fotbollsgalan%202000">Swedish Soccer Awards</a>, and during her speech she expressed her thoughts that women's soccer received too little media publicity. She played for <a href="Aln%C3%B6%20IF">Alnö IF</a>, <a href="Sundsvalls%20DFF">Sundsvalls DFF</a> and Umeå IK. She retired from playing football aged 25 after suffering from <a href="anorexia%20nervosa">anorexia nervosa</a>.
In her youth years she, except for playing soccer, also practiced <a href="alpine%20skiing">alpine skiing</a>, <a href="bandy">bandy</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a> and <a href="golf">golf</a>.
Club career.
After the 1998 season, Nordlund approached English <a href="FA%20Women%27s%20Premier%20League">FA Women's Premier League</a> club <a href="Tranmere%20Rovers%20L.F.C.">Tranmere Rovers</a> about playing for them in <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20FA%20Women%27s%20Premier%20League">1998–99</a>. At the time she was visiting boyfriend <a href="Jesper%20Blomqvist">Jesper Blomqvist</a>, who was contracted to <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>.
Making her debut in a 4–0 win over champions and local rivals <a href="Everton%20L.F.C.">Everton</a> in December 1998, Nordlund remained until 1 February 1999. She then returned to Umeå IK in order to preserve her national team place ahead of the <a href="1999%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">1999 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>.
International career.
After winning eight <a href="Cap%20%28sports%29">caps</a> at Under 17 level and 19 Under 21 caps, Nordlund made her senior <a href="Sweden%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> debut in a 3–1 defeat by the <a href="United%20States%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">United States</a> at <a href="Baylor%20School">Baylor School</a>, <a href="Chattanooga%2C%20Tennessee">Chattanooga, Tennessee</a>, on 30 October 1997. Her 9th minute goal against <a href="Denmark%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a> in the Semi-Final of the <a href="UEFA%20Women%27s%20Euro%202001%23Semi-finals">2001 UEFA Women's Euro</a> proved to be the deciding goal of the match, propelling Sweden to the Final.
Personal life.
Nordlund appeared in the 2006 Swedish comedy film "<a href="Offside%20%282006%20Swedish%20film%29">Offside</a>", as a football player. She is a <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">Lazio</a> supporter.
She has been married to Swedish television presenter <a href="Martin%20Bj%C3%B6rk">Martin Björk</a>.
